message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The irregularity, stenosis, and poststenotic dilation involving the proximal right subclavian artery suggest Takayasu's arteritis. Prednisone is initiated to suppress the inflammation, but the patient still has hypertension, which can be treated with Carvedilol + hydrochlorothiazide. Plasmapheresis or Rituximab may be considered in refractory cases, but not as a first-line treatment. Surgery should only be considered if there are complications, such as aneurysm, severe stenosis or symptoms despite medical treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation and laboratory studies suggest Takayasu's arteritis, and the MRI confirms the diagnosis. The arterial irregularity, stenosis, and poststenotic dilation involve the proximal right subclavian artery. The most appropriate next step in patient management is to initiate treatment with beta-blockers and diuretics like Carvedilol and hydrochlorothiazide to control hypertension. Surgery may be considered if medical treatment fails. Plasmapheresis and Rituximab are not recommended as first-line therapy in Takayasu's arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a subclavian steal syndrome causing decreased blood flow to her right arm, resulting in atrophy. Prednisone improves the symptoms, but the irregularity, stenosis, and poststenotic dilation indicate a structural problem. Carvedilol and hydrochlorothiazide can help manage hypertension and improve blood flow. Plasmapheresis and rituximab target autoimmune disorders, which are not indicated for this patient. Surgery can correct the structural problem, but it is usually reserved for patients who fail medical treatment or have severe symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the results of the MRI suggest Takayasu arteritis, a condition that causes inflammation of large blood vessels. The appropriate next step would be to initiate treatment with a beta blocker such as carvedilol and a diuretic such as hydrochlorothiazide to manage the hypertension. Surgery may be considered if medical therapy fails, but it is not the next step in management. Plasmapheresis and rituximab may be used in certain cases, but they are not the first-line treatment for Takayasu arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The irregularity, stenosis, and poststenotic dilation of the proximal right subclavian artery suggest Takayasu arteritis. Prednisone has been shown to improve symptoms of Takayasu arteritis, so continuing treatment with a beta-blocker and diuretic combination like carvedilol and hydrochlorothiazide may be the best next step to manage the hypertension. Surgery may be necessary if medical therapy fails. Plasmapheresis and rituximab are not standard treatments for Takayasu arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results indicate Takayasu arteritis, and the MRI confirmed stenosis of the proximal right subclavian artery. The management for Takayasu arteritis includes corticosteroids, which the patient has already initiated. Carvedilol + hydrochlorothiazide can be added to manage hypertension caused by the disease. Plasmapheresis or rituximab may be used in refractory cases but are not the initial management options. Surgery may also be considered in severe cases with irreparable arterial damage, but it is not the next step in management in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The irregularity, stenosis, and poststenotic dilation involving the proximal right subclavian artery indicates subclavian steal syndrome. Prednisone helps alleviate symptoms but does not treat the underlying cause. Carvedilol and hydrochlorothiazide are used to control hypertension, which can be a complication of subclavian steal syndrome. Plasmapheresis and rituximab are not indicated in the management of subclavian steal syndrome. Surgery may be necessary in severe cases, but initial management should start with medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The irregularity, stenosis, and poststenotic dilation involving the proximal right subclavian artery suggest Takayasu arteritis. Prednisone is initiated with improvement of her symptoms, and Carvedilol + hydrochlorothiazide is the most appropriate next step in the patient management to manage hypertension. Plasmapheresis is indicated in some cases of refractory disease, but not as first-line treatment. Rituximab and surgery are not indicated in the initial management of Takayasu arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has Takayasu arteritis, an autoimmune disease that affects the aorta and its branches. Prednisone is the first-line treatment for Takayasu arteritis, which should be continued. Carvedilol + hydrochlorothiazide is used to control blood pressure and would be appropriate for the patient since she has hypertension. Plasmapheresis and Rituximab could be considered in refractory cases, but they are not the first-line treatment. Surgery may be considered in severe cases, but it is not the next appropriate step in this patient's management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest Takayasu arteritis, which can cause hypertension and arterial stenosis. Prednisone can be used to manage inflammation, but the artery stenosis may still require treatment. Carvedilol and hydrochlorothiazide can help manage hypertension caused by arterial stenosis. Surgery may be considered if medical management is unsuccessful or if there is significant end-organ damage. Plasmapheresis and rituximab are not indicated for Takayasu arteritis.
